trans-unit.source: Configuring a WCF Service
trans-unit.target: Configuring a WCF Service

trans-unit.source: Configuring a WCF Service to Register with Service Bus
trans-unit.target: Configuring a WCF Service to Register with Service Bus

trans-unit.source: Configuring an application that uses <token>sb1</token> requires that you set the following properties:
trans-unit.target: Configuring an application that uses <token>sb1</token> requires that you set the following properties:

trans-unit.source: The name of the service you are exposing.
trans-unit.target: The name of the service you are exposing.

trans-unit.source: The interface (representing the service contract) your application either exposes or connects through.
trans-unit.target: The interface (representing the service contract) your application either exposes or connects through.

trans-unit.source: The type of binding your application uses, which includes transport, security, and encoding settings.
trans-unit.target: The type of binding your application uses, which includes transport, security, and encoding settings.

trans-unit.source: The address at which the contract is available.
trans-unit.target: The address at which the contract is available.

trans-unit.source: When using <token>indigo2</token> you can set these properties in an <token>indigo2</token> service or client application either programmatically or in an App.config file.
trans-unit.target: When using <token>indigo2</token> you can set these properties in an <token>indigo2</token> service or client application either programmatically or in an App.config file.

trans-unit.source: However, it is usually best to specify the binding and address information declaratively in a configuration file, instead of imperatively in code unless your specific scenario requires it.
trans-unit.target: However, it is usually best to specify the binding and address information declaratively in a configuration file, instead of imperatively in code unless your specific scenario requires it.

trans-unit.source: Defining endpoints in code is usually not practical because the bindings and addresses for a deployed service are typically different from those used as the service is being developed.
trans-unit.target: Defining endpoints in code is usually not practical because the bindings and addresses for a deployed service are typically different from those used as the service is being developed.

trans-unit.source: More generally, keeping the binding and addressing information out of the code enables them to change without having to recompile or redeploy the application.
trans-unit.target: More generally, keeping the binding and addressing information out of the code enables them to change without having to recompile or redeploy the application.

trans-unit.source: The following list contains the general scenarios for configuring a <token>sb2</token> application.
trans-unit.target: The following list contains the general scenarios for configuring a <token>sb2</token> application.

trans-unit.source: For additional information about how to configure a <token>indigo2</token> application, see <link xlink:href="beac771e-f28e-4f84-9ff1-ad9251c726d3" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Configuring Services</link> in the <token>indigo2</token> documentation.
trans-unit.target: For additional information about how to configure a <token>indigo2</token> application, see <link xlink:href="beac771e-f28e-4f84-9ff1-ad9251c726d3" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Configuring Services</link> in the <token>indigo2</token> documentation.

trans-unit.source: Basic Application
trans-unit.target: Basic Application

trans-unit.source: This type of application is a <token>indigo2</token> SOAP-based application that is configured to use <token>sb2</token> as a secured relay to connect to other applications.
trans-unit.target: This type of application is a <token>indigo2</token> SOAP-based application that is configured to use <token>sb2</token> as a secured relay to connect to other applications.

trans-unit.source: The only differences required to use <token>sb2</token> are the type of binding and the endpoint address.
trans-unit.target: The only differences required to use <token>sb2</token> are the type of binding and the endpoint address.

trans-unit.source: <token>indigo2</token> applications that use <token>sb2</token> use one of the relay bindings available in the SDK; bindings that have authentication and transport elements not present in the standard <token>indigo2</token> bindings.
trans-unit.target: <token>indigo2</token> applications that use <token>sb2</token> use one of the relay bindings available in the SDK; bindings that have authentication and transport elements not present in the standard <token>indigo2</token> bindings.

trans-unit.source: Similarly, the endpoint address that is used for the service endpoint is a <token>sb2</token> URI based on the registered <token>sb2</token> namespace name (and may also have a different protocol scheme), whereas a regular <token>indigo2</token> application uses an address based on the local host.
trans-unit.target: Similarly, the endpoint address that is used for the service endpoint is a <token>sb2</token> URI based on the registered <token>sb2</token> namespace name (and may also have a different protocol scheme), whereas a regular <token>indigo2</token> application uses an address based on the local host.

trans-unit.source: Because these are the only two configuration differences, you can often – but not always – just reconfigure a currently existing <token>indigo2</token> application to expose its services through the <token>sb2</token>
trans-unit.target: Because these are the only two configuration differences, you can often – but not always – just reconfigure a currently existing <token>indigo2</token> application to expose its services through the <token>sb2</token>

trans-unit.source: REST-based Application
trans-unit.target: REST-based Application

trans-unit.source: The topics in this documentation describe are two types of REST applications: those that use the <token>indigo2</token> web programming model and the Azure SDK, and one that does not.
trans-unit.target: The topics in this documentation describe are two types of REST applications: those that use the <token>indigo2</token> web programming model and the Azure SDK, and one that does not.

trans-unit.source: However, the topics in this section only describe REST applications that use the Azure SDK as a programming foundation.
trans-unit.target: However, the topics in this section only describe REST applications that use the Azure SDK as a programming foundation.

trans-unit.source: If your application does use the Azure SDK, you can configure your application in the same way as any other REST-based <token>indigo2</token> service: you must use a relay binding that supports HTTP, such as <codeEntityReference>T:Microsoft.ServiceBus.WebHttpRelayBinding</codeEntityReference> or <codeEntityReference>T:Microsoft.ServiceBus.WS2007HttpRelayBinding</codeEntityReference>, and you must apply the appropriate <token>indigo2</token> attributes to your interface, and confirm that your implementation can send and receive HTTP messages and events.
trans-unit.target: If your application does use the Azure SDK, you can configure your application in the same way as any other REST-based <token>indigo2</token> service: you must use a relay binding that supports HTTP, such as <codeEntityReference>T:Microsoft.ServiceBus.WebHttpRelayBinding</codeEntityReference> or <codeEntityReference>T:Microsoft.ServiceBus.WS2007HttpRelayBinding</codeEntityReference>, and you must apply the appropriate <token>indigo2</token> attributes to your interface, and confirm that your implementation can send and receive HTTP messages and events.

trans-unit.source: <token>crdefault</token> <link xlink:href="dfaace1b-c418-4e06-83cf-0261144ebd7a" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Designing an AppFabric Service Bus Contract</link>.
trans-unit.target: <token>crdefault</token> <link xlink:href="dfaace1b-c418-4e06-83cf-0261144ebd7a" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Designing an AppFabric Service Bus Contract</link>.
